I would recommend checking out 'Zero Effect'. It is a comedy-drama film directed by Jake Kasdan and starring Ryan O'Neal, Tom Berenger, Nick Chinlund, Harris Yulin, Terry Crews, Snoop Dogg, Snoop Dogg.
The film follows the story of Daryl Zero (Ryan O'Neal) who is an alcoholic private detective. He gets a job to investigate the missing keys for a shady tycoon Gregory Stark (Tom Berenger). Along his journey, he encounters his estranged father Steve Arlo (Nick Chinlund) who has been working as a hitman for Gregory Stark.
The film combines elements of comedy and drama. It explores themes of redemption, family, and loyalty.
Overall, 'Zero Effect' is an entertaining and engaging film that combines elements of comedy and drama.

The story follows three people who are struggling for survival behind the Red banners and slogans. Kira wants to be a builder, and Leo and Andrei love her.

In their tensely dramatic story, Ayn Rand shows what the theories of Communism mean in practice.

We the Living is not a story of politics but of the men and women who have to struggle for existence behind the Red banners and slogans.

Based on your preference cues, I would recommend "Minority Report" by Paul Thomas Anderson.

The movie tells the story of a group of PreCogs who are able to predict crimes before they take place. However, when one of these pre-cogs predicts that a man named John will commit murder in three days, things get complicated as John is actually innocent and has been framed for the crime. ThePreCogs must now race against time to clear John's name and bring justice to him.

The movie stars Paul Thomas Anderson himself as PreCognitive John "J" Smith. He also stars Elizabeth Stone as PreCognitive Dr. Eve McNeil, and Mark Ruffalo as PreCognitive Detective Donny Landers.
